days.title: The First Line of Code You MUST Write 🤯
days.hook: Stop scrolling! If you want to code, you HAVE to start here.
days.code: print('Hello, World!')
days.explanation: Alright, let’s kick things off! The print function shows text on your screen. Whatever you put inside the quotes gets displayed — just like saying hello to Python!

days.title: Variables: The DNA of Coding 🧬
days.hook: Imagine a box that can hold ANYTHING. That's a variable.
days.code:
name = 'Python'
print(name)
days.explanation: Variables are like boxes that hold information. Here, we stored the word ‘Python’ in a box called name, and print it out!

days.title: Math in Python is INSANE ⚡
days.hook: Throw away your calculator. Python is faster.
days.code:
x = 5
y = 3
print(x + y)
days.explanation: Python can do math too! Add, subtract, multiply, divide — just like your calculator but in code!

days.title: Make Your Code TALK Back 🗣️
days.hook: Want your code to actually listen to you? Watch this.
days.code:
name = input('Enter your name: ')
print('Hello', name)
days.explanation: Want to talk to the user? The input function lets them type something, and you can use it right after — just like saying hello personally!

days.title: The 'Age' Glitch in Python ⚠️
days.hook: Warning! Your age is NOT a number in Python... yet.
days.code:
age = int(input('Age? '))
print(age + 1)
days.explanation: Inputs are text by default! If you don't use 'int()', Python thinks your age is a word. Convert it, or your math will break!

days.title: Merging Words Like Magic 🪄
days.hook: You can literally glue words together in code.
days.code:
first = 'Py'
second = 'thon'
print(first + second)
days.explanation: You can join two strings using a plus sign! It’s like sticking two words together to make a new one.

days.title: The Ultimate String Hack (f-strings) 🔥
days.hook: Stop using plus signs! Do this instead.
days.code:
name = 'Alex'
print(f'Hi {name}')
days.explanation: See that 'f'? It stands for Fast. Or Format. Doesn't matter. It lets you put variables RIGHT inside the text. Clean. Professional.

days.title: How Computers Make Decisions 🧠
days.hook: Your code has a brain. Here is how it thinks.
days.explanation: If statements let you make decisions. If the condition is true, Python runs the code inside — simple logic power!

days.title: The 'Else' Universe 🌌
days.hook: What happens if the answer is NO?
days.explanation: If something isn’t true, the else block runs instead. It’s like saying: if not this, then that!

days.title: Grading System in 3 Lines 📝
days.hook: I built a teacher in 3 lines of code.
days.explanation: Elif means ‘else if’. You can check multiple conditions one after another — perfect for grading systems!

days.title: Lists: The Super Variable 📦
days.hook: Why have 10 variables when you can have 1?
days.code:
fruits = ['apple', 'nbna']
print(fruits[0])
days.explanation: A List is a backpack. Throw anything in it. Pull it out by its number. Index 0 is the first item. Always.

days.title: Infinite List Glitch? ♾️
days.hook: You can add items to lists forever.
days.code:
items = []
items.append('Gold')
print(items)
days.explanation: .append() is your best friend. It pushes new data to the end of the line. Your list grows as your data grows.

days.title: The Loop of Infinity 🔄
days.hook: Don't repeat yourself. Let Python do it.
days.code:
for i in range(3):
    print('Hello')
days.explanation: Loops repeat code! The range(3) makes it run three times — like hitting replay on your code.

days.title: Scanning Data Like a Pro 🕵️
days.hook: How does Instagram show all your photos?
days.explanation: For loops can walk through each item in a list — super handy for working with collections!

days.title: The Loop That NEVER Ends ⚠️
days.hook: Warning: This loop could crash your computer.
days.code:
x = 1
while x < 4:
    print(x)
    x += 1
days.explanation: While loops run until the condition becomes false. It’s like saying — keep going until you’re done!

days.title: Defining Your Own Powers 🦸
days.hook: You can invent your own Python commands.
days.explanation: Functions are reusable blocks of code! Define once, call anytime — just like shortcuts for your logic.

days.title: Functions Level 2: Arguments ⚔️
days.hook: Make your functions smarter.
days.explanation: We passed 'Bro' INTO the function. It's like feeding a machine. Input goes in, action comes out.

days.title: The Function Payback 💰
days.hook: Functions can give you things back.
days.explanation: Return sends data back from a function. Think of it like answering a question — you send the result back!

days.title: Lazy Coding Hacks (Defaults) 😴
days.hook: Too lazy to type? Python has your back.
days.explanation: Default parameters kick in when no value is given — super useful for quick function calls.

days.title: Slicing Data Ninja Style 🗡️
days.hook: Grab exactly what you want from any list.
days.code:
nums = [1,2,3,4,5]
print(nums[1:4])
days.explanation: Slicing helps you grab parts of a list — from index 1 up to (but not including) 4.

days.title: Tuples in Python
days.code:
colors = ('red', 'green', 'blue')
print(colors[0])
days.explanation: Tuples are like lists but can’t be changed. Perfect for data you want to keep safe.

days.title: Dictionaries
days.code:
person = {'name': 'Alex', 'age': 25}
print(person['name'])
days.explanation: Dictionaries store data in key-value pairs — just like a contact book where each name has info!

days.title: Adding to a Dictionary
days.explanation: You can easily add new key-value pairs — dictionaries are super flexible!

days.title: If in a List
days.explanation: You can check if an item exists using ‘in’. It’s a quick way to search through lists.

days.title: Nested Loops
days.explanation: Loops inside loops — perfect for grids, patterns, or combinations!

days.title: Break Statement
days.explanation: Break stops the loop early — great when you’ve found what you were looking for!

days.title: Continue Statement
days.explanation: Continue skips the current loop step — like saying ‘skip this one, move on!’

days.title: Nested If
days.explanation: You can put if statements inside each other — that’s called nesting. Super handy for detailed checks!

days.title: Bulletproof Code (Try/Except) 🛡️
days.hook: Stop your code from crashing.
days.explanation: You tried to divide by zero! That crashes programs. But 'Except' catches the crash and handles it safely.

days.title: Mini Project: Greeting App
days.code:
name = input('Your name: ')
print(f'Welcome to Python, {name}!')
days.explanation: Congrats! You’ve learned the basics. This simple app greets the user — and shows how input, variables, and f-strings come together!

days.title: Looping Smart with Counters 🫪e
days.hook: Stop counting manually like a caveman.
days.explanation: Enumerate gives you the item AND its position. No more manually counting i = 0 then i += 1!

days.title: Zipping Lists Together 🤐
days.hook: Two lists? One loop. Watch this.
days.code:
names = ['Leo', 'Neo']
powers = ['Fire', 'Ice']
for n, p in zip(names, powers):
    print(f'{n} uses {p}')
days.output:
Leo uses Fire
Neo uses Ice
days.explanation: Zip stitches two lists together like a zipper! Perfect for pairing data without complex loops.

days.title: The Duplicate Killer (Sets) 🚫
days.hook: Remove duplicates in ONE line of code.
days.code:
ids = [1, 2, 2, 3]
unique_ids = set(ids)
print(unique_ids)
days.explanation: Sets are collections that refuse duplicates. Convert a list to a set, and all repeats vanish instantly!

days.title: Venna Diagram Logic (Set Ops) 🥨
days.hook: Find common items between two groups instantly.
days.explanation: The & operator finds the intersection—items that exist in BOTH sets. It’s math magic in Python!

days.title: One-Line Loop Magic ✨
days.hook: Write a 3-line loop in 1 line.
days.code:
nums = [1, 2, 3]
squared = [x**2 for x in nums]
print(squared)
days.explanation: List comprehensions let you run a loop inside a list! It’s cleaner, faster, and makes you look like a pro.

days.title: The Code That Never Dies (Finally) 🧹
days.hook: Make sure your code cleans up its mess.
days.explanation: Finally runs no matter what—error or no error. It’s perfect for cleaning up messes or closing files.

days.title: Stopping the Chaos (Raise Exception) 🛑
days.hook: You can force your program to crash. Here is why.
days.explanation: Sometimes you WANT your program to crash if data is bad. Raise lets you trigger your own errors!

days.title: Unlimited Arguments (*args) 🌌
days.hook: Pass 1, 10, or 100 arguments. No errors.
days.explanation: The * lets you pass as many arguments as you want! Python packs them all into a tuple called nums.

days.title: Labelled Arguments (**kwargs) 🏷️
days.hook: Getting messy with arguments? Label them!
days.explanation: The ** gathers named arguments into a dictionary. It’s perfect for functions that need flexibility!

days.title: Anonymous Functions (Lambda) 👻
days.hook: A function with no name? Spooky.
days.code:
square = lambda x: x ** 2
print(square(5))
days.explanation: Lambdas are tiny, one-line functions without a name. Great for quick math or sorting tricks!

days.title: Math Power Unlimited ♾️
days.hook: Your calculator is jealous.
days.code:
import math
print(math.sqrt(16))
print(math.ceil(2.1))
days.explanation: Math module is your scientific calculator. Square roots, trigonometry, rounding—it’s all there!

days.title: Let Fate Decide (Random) 🎲
days.hook: Can't decide what to eat? Let Python pick.
days.code:
import random
choices = ['Pizza', 'Sushi']
print(random.choice(choices))
days.explanation: Can't decide? Let Python pick! random.choice is perfect for games, lotteries, or dinner plans.

days.title: Making Python Wait (Time) ⏳
days.hook: Add suspense to your code.
days.code:
import time
print('Loading...')
time.sleep(2)
print('Done!')
days.explanation: time.sleep() pauses your program. Essential for dramatic effect, countdowns, or waiting for data.

days.title: What Time Is It? ⌚
days.hook: Track the exact moment in time.
days.code:
import datetime
now = datetime.datetime.now()
print(now.strftime('%H:%M:%S'))
days.explanation: Computers live by the clock. datetime lets you grab the exact moment, format it, and track time.

days.title: Hacking Your File System (OS) 📂
days.hook: Control your computer's folders with code.
days.code:
import os
print(os.getcwd())
days.explanation: The OS module lets you talk to your operating system. Find out where you are, list files, or make folders!

days.title: Saving Your Secrets (Write) 💾
days.hook: Save your data so it doesn't vanish.
days.code:
file = open('secret.txt', 'w')
file.write('This is hidden.')
file.close()
days.explanation: Programs usually forget everything when they stop. Writing to a file saves your data FOREVER (until you delete it).

days.title: Reading Your Secrets Back 📖
days.hook: Read the file you just saved.
days.code:
file = open('secret.txt', 'r')
content = file.read()
print(content)
file.close()
days.explanation: Reading brings data back into your program. Only existing files can be read, or Python crashes!

days.title: The Never-Ending Log (Append) 📝
days.hook: Add to a file without deleting the old stuff.
days.code:
file = open('log.txt', 'a')
file.write('New entry!\n')
file.close()
days.explanation: Start mode 'w' wipes the file clean. Mode 'a' (append) adds to the end—perfect for diaries or logs!

days.title: The Safety Net (With Open) 🛡️
days.hook: Never forget to close a file again.
days.code:
with open('data.txt', 'w') as f:
    f.write('Safe!')
# File closes automatically here
days.explanation: Forget file.close()? Python has your back. The with block closes the file automatically, even if errors happen!

days.title: Saving Complicated Data (JSON) 📦
days.hook: Save entire lists and dictionaries easily.
days.code:
import json
data = {'name': 'Max', 'level': 5}
saved = json.dumps(data)
print(saved)
days.explanation: Text files are boring. JSON lets you save Lists and Dictionaries as text, then load them back perfectly!

days.title: Your First Blueprint (Class) 🏗️
days.hook: Build your own custom objects.
days.code:
class Robot:
    pass

my_bot = Robot()
print(my_bot)
days.explanation: A Class is a blueprint. An Object is the thing you build from it. We just built an empty robot!

days.title: Bringing It To Life (__init__) ⚡
days.hook: Give your objects a soul.
days.explanation: The __init__ function runs AUTOMATICALLY when you create an object. It’s the spark of life!

days.title: Giving It Personality (Self) 🏷️
days.hook: Why do we use 'self' everywhere?
days.explanation: Self refers to the specific object being built. self.name attaches the name tag to THIS robot.

days.title: Teaching Robots Tricks (Methods) 🦾
days.hook: Make your objects DO things.
days.explanation: Methods are just functions inside a class. They let objects DO things, like speak or move.

days.title: Shared Knowledge (Class Vars) 🧠
days.hook: Variables shared by EVERY object.
days.code:
class Robot:
    laws = 3

a = Robot()
b = Robot()
print(a.laws, b.laws)
days.explanation: Class variables are shared by ALL objects. Every robot knows the 3 laws!

days.title: The Robot Family (Inheritance) 👨‍👦
days.hook: Code once, use everywhere.
days.explanation: Robots inherit from Machines! They get all the parent’s abilities for free. Less code, more power.

days.title: Rebelling Against Parents (Override) 🤘
days.hook: Change how inherited methods work.
days.explanation: Child classes can change how inherited methods work. A car starts differently than a washing machine!

days.title: Who Are You? (__str__) 🆔
days.hook: Make printing objects look beautiful.
days.code:
class Cat:
    def __str__(self): return 'Meow'

c = Cat()
print(c)
days.explanation: By default, printing an object looks ugly. __str__ lets you decide what an object looks like as text!

days.title: Making Your Own Tools (Modules) 🛠️
days.hook: Create your own 'import' commands.
days.code:
# In file bot.py
def speak(): print('Hi')

# In main.py
import bot
bot.speak()
days.explanation: Any Python file is a module! Save your functions in one file, import them in another. Organize your life.

days.title: Mini Project: RPG Character ⚔️
days.hook: Build a game character with stats.
days.code:
class Hero:
    def __init__(self, hp): self.hp = hp
    def heal(self): self.hp += 10

p = Hero(50)
p.heal()
print(p.hp)
days.explanation: You made a video game character! It has health, and it can heal. This is the power of OOP!
